ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TOTAL DEFENCE CONCEPT
(Mobilization)


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence whether, as part of the Total Defence concept in which National Service plays a very dominant role, he has any plans to speed up the process of mobilization of reservists as the present system of such mobilization leaves much to be desired in view of what is happening in the region; and, if so, when such a process will be implemented and whether it will cause alarm to the public.

    The Minister of State for Defence and Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the SAF has successfully practised Silent Mobilization of reservists for many years. This involves using a courier system to alert reservists.

    But responsive as Silent Mobilization is, there may be situations where the SAF has to mobilize reservists much faster. To do this, the SAF will adopt Open Mobilization in which the mass media - radio, television, Rediffusion and the cinema - are used to direct reservists to report to their mobilization centres. The first practice will be held later this year.

    There will be no reason for the public to be alarmed. The first announcement of the Open Mobilization exercise will be made at

Column: 810

least a month beforehand. The date will then be regularly announced over radio and television two weeks before the practice event. Two days prior to the practice, press announcements will also be made. The public will therefore not be caught by surprise.

    That the SAF should hold such mobilization exercises does not mean that war is around the corner. These exercises will allow the SAF to test the system in peacetime so that it can function well if a real need should arise. Repeated practices will mean a well honed and dependable system. This will, in turn, help strengthen public confidence in our Reserve National Service system.

    If Open Mobilization is to work well, every citizen who hears the mobilization message should contact relatives and friends who are reservists, and ask them to turn on their radio or TV set. Only then will we get the fastest possible response from reservists. Employers can play their special part by immediately releasing affected reservists who are at work. It is clear that the public and employers, and not only reservists, are critical to the success of Open Mobilization.

    Peace and security come from effective deterrence. Success in deterrence lies in Singaporeans showing their willingness and ability to contribute in Total Defence. Open Mobilization exercises will give the public and employers the opportunity to demonstrate their commitment by the way they play their part.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister of State for Defence and Trade and Industry how effective will this Open Mobilization system be, and what impact will it have on the reservists and the people as a whole?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, just to give some sense of scale, to mobilize silently, using couriers and messengers, it takes altogether 30 hours for a unit to get ready - 24 hours to bring the people back, and six hours for them to get prepared, equipped, and in battle order. With Open Mobilization, we hope to reduce this time to 12 hours, which means six hours to get the people back, assuming we can reach all of them simultaneously,

Column: 811

and six hours to get them ready and equipped for war.

    Can we get all of them back within six hours? A lot depends on how keyed up and clued up the reservists are, and how quickly they respond to the mobilization notices. We can broadcast a message throughout Singapore within a few minutes. It is up to the reservists who have received this message to return as quickly as they can. It is also up to the family members to inform them, if they are not at home and not reachable by television, to go back to camp as quickly as possible. So how many per cent of our reservists we can get back in six hours is yet to be seen. We hope that it will be as good as the system which we have developed using Silent Mobilization.

Column: 811

DEATHS OF OFFICER CADET
TAN PENG KIAN AND PTE LEOW KOK BENG


    2. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence whether the Committees of Inquiry appointed to inquire into the deaths of Pte Leow Kok Beng, National Serviceman, on the 31st of January 1985 and Officer Cadet Tan Peng Kian on the 2nd of February 1985 have completed their investigations and submitted their reports and whether the Minister will make available to Parliament the reports.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the inquiries into the deaths of national servicemen of PTE Leow Kok Beng and OCT Tan Peng. Kian are still in progress. They are expected to be completed by early May 1985.

    The Minister for Defence stated in written answer to a similar question by the Member for Anson on 19 October 1984, that the death of a serviceman, especially a national serviceman, is a matter of grave concern, not only to the Ministry of Defence, but also to the general public. He gives the assurance again that whenever a serviceman is killed or seriously injured in service, the Armed Forces Council, chaired

Column: 812

by the Minister for Defence, directs an investigation into the matter. The board of inquiry is chaired by a senior officer from a different unit, or even a different Ministry, who has nothing to do with the incident. It investigates not only the immediate cause of the death or injury, but also the training the serviceman was involved in, and whether remedial or disciplinary actions are called for. The board reports directly to the Armed Forces Council, which follows up the case with the full resources of the Ministry of Defence.

    As for making public the results of the investigations, under the law, the deaths of PTE Leow and OCT Tan would be the subject of Coroner's inquiries. All facts relevant and material to their deaths would be investigated by the police and tendered in evidence to the State Coroner. The practice in the Coroner's Inquiries is to allow the next-of-kin of the deceased persons, either by themselves or their solicitors, to examine and challenge these facts, and also to tender their own evidence, if any. All these would be evaluated by the State Coroner who would make his findings accordingly. Coroner's Inquiries are public inquiries, Their proceedings are open to public scrutiny. The findings of the Coroner would be conclusive as regards the death of the deceased persons.

    The boards of inquiry established by the Minister for Defence do not have the powers of the State Coroner, and rightly so. Their witnesses are not protected by the same rules of evidence as those that apply in the courts. The publication of the board's reports could therefore meet with legal difficulties. Besides, there may be security objections in making public the reports, as the boards investigate also the training the servicemen were involved in and the remedial actions to be taken. It is therefore unnecessary and inappropriate to make public the reports into the deaths of PTE Leow and OCT Tan.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I enquire from the Minister of State whether the reports of the Committees of Inquiry, or are they Boards of Inquiry in these present cases, will be submitted to the Coroner?

Column: 813



     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the reports in this case will be from the Committees of Inquiry. They will not be submitted to the Coroner because they are not admissible evidence under the law.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I know whether the witnesses, if any, who are heard by these Committees will be produced before the Coroner?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the learned Member for Anson is aware of the procedures for Coroner's inquiries. The Coroner has the power to call any witnesses he thinks fit.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware of those powers. Is the Minister aware that unless the Coroner knows who the potential witnesses are, he cannot issue a subpoena for them to attend b&ore him? The question is, will the military make available to him the full details of the investigation. Secondly, will the reports be made available to the parents at least?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Coroner works on the basis of a police investigation, which proceeds independently of the SAF investigation. He knows which witness he wishes to call. As I have stated, the report of the Committees of Inquiry and boards of inquiry are privileged documents, and they are therefore not given to anybody outside of the working agencies.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Hon. Minister aware that in the case of OCT Tan Peng Kian, his family had been given conflicting reports about the time of the death of this officer?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think we are entering into the facts of the case, which I am very reluctant to do because the Coroner has not yet ruled. I would say that issues such as time of death are questions of fact, not of opinion, and they will be determined by the Coroner and by the police investigation, and that the SAF will abide by whatever the facts are as they come out.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Finally, is the Minister aware that this family was not informed at least, I am told, three hours after the officer's death? Is there any reason for this delay ?

Column: 814



     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not see the relevance of the supplementary question to the original one.

VACANT COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS AND PRIVATE APARTMENTS
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many hotel rooms and offices in commercial buildings have remained vacant or unoccupied since completion in the last 12 months; (b) how many private apartments and houses have remained vacant or unoccupied since completion in the last 12 months; (c) whether his Ministry will buy over some of these hotels or commercial buildings and convert them to public use such as government offices and welfare and recreation centres; and (d) whether the Housing and Development Board will purchase some of these vacant private apartments and houses and sell them to interested buyers under the public housing scheme.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, 235,599 sq metres of offices and 5,284 residential housing units were completed between October 1983 and September 1984. Of the completed office areas and housing units, 96,972 sq metres or 41.2% of the offices and 2,429 units or 46.0% of the housing units were vacant at the end of September 1984. My Ministry does not monitor the occupancy rates of hotel rooms. That is the responsibility of the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board. The Board has estimated that the occupancy rate of 2,385 additional new hotel rooms in 1984 averaged 65.8% versus a national average of 75.5% for 16,440 rooms.

    Neither the Ministry nor the Housing and Development Board has plans to purchase any of the vacant office space, hotel rooms or housing units. Individual government ministries decide how and where their activities are to be carried out. If there is a need for them to purchase some of the vacant office space or hotel rooms, they can take up the matter directly with the Ministry of Finance.

    Private residential properties cater to the needs of people who do not qualify for

Column: 815

public housing units built by the Housing and Development Board. It is not within the Board's objective to buy over such units for resale to interested buyers. It is also not necessary to do so. Interested buyers can negotiate with private developers directly.

Column: 815

HDB HOME OWNERSHIP SCHEME
(Measures to Promote)


    4. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for National Development (a) in view of its recent liberalisation of the property ownership rules, whether the Housing and Development Board will raise or even waive the ceiling of income in order to make it easier for people to purchase types of flats according to their needs; (b) whether the HDB will waive the present age requirement so that two single adults can apply to rent HDB flats; and (c) whether the HDB will allow single persons alone to purchase one or two-room flats in the foreseeable future.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the current income ceilings of $3,500 per month for HDB flats and $6,000 per month for HUDC flats already bring public housing within the reach of more than 90% of the population. However, the HDB continually reviews the ceilings. An upward revision will be made when the need arises.

    In view of land constraints, public housing is limited and must therefore be confined to the accommodation of family units. The HDB is unable to waive the present age requirement to cater for single citizens who wish to stay on their own, away from their parents or family.

    For similar reasons, the HDB is unable to allow single persons to purchase 1- or 2-room flats. These flats are currently rented out to the lower income section of the population. When not required anymore, they will be converted to bigger sale flats or demolished for redevelopment, to meet the demand from families.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin (Nee Soon): Sir, will the Minister consider the possibility of allowing single persons who are brothers and sisters, whose parents are owners of

Column: 816

property or HDB flats and whose family members exceed a certain number, to apply for HDB flats because it is too difficult for them to live in one HDB flat?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the HDB rule is that one flat will be allocated to each family. In other words, the family with a large number of children will not be given a special privilege over the family with a smaller number of children.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta)( In Mandarin): Sir, will the Minister tell the House whether the HDB at present will allow single persons to rent HDB flats?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan( In Mandarin): Sir, the present HDB regulations allow a single person together with another person to rent or to buy HDB flats. However, in the case of a male, he must be at least 50 years old and, in the case of a female, 40 years old. The reason for such regulations is that in our society, those who are above 40 do not have much chance of getting married. Therefore, it is difficult for them to set up their own families and the Government allows them to rent or to buy a flat together with another person.

    As for the male citizen, if he is above 40, he still has the opportunity of getting married. However, if he is above 50 years old, the chances of his getting married are very slim. Therefore, the Government allows him, together with another person, to rent or to buy an HDB flat.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok( In Mandarin): Sir, my point is that if both are males who are above 30 years old, will the Minister allow them to rent or to buy an HDB flat? We cannot force them to get married. If they are unable to get suitable spouses and if they are paying tax, will the Minister consider allowing them to rent or to buy an HDB flat?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, the HDB will not consider changing these regulations.

Column: 816

REDUCTION OF RENTALS
FOR COMMERCIAL AND
INDUSTRIAL PREMISES


    5. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether the

Column: 817

Urban Redevelopment Authority and Housing and Development Board will consider freezing or even reducing rentals for business or industrial premises and shophouses for this year in view of the present hard times and whether his Ministry has received any such request; and (b) whether the HDB will consider downward revision of the prices of its flats in the light of prices in the present property market.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB and the URA systems of renting out business premises are different from each other. URA shop premises are let out on fixed leases of 2-3 years. The rentals of URA premises are determined at the commencement of the leases with reference to market rates, On expiry of the leases, rentals are reviewed and adjusted in accordance with prevailing market conditions.

    In the case of the HDB, premises are let out on monthly tenancies and rentals are determined by the tender system. There are no specific time periods at the end of which rentals are revised. The HDB has since its inception only revised shop rentals once. This was in 1983 when the rentals of premises let out as far back as the Fifties were brought up to the 1980 level. This was because of the vast disparities in rents set more than 20 years ago and which had not been revised. Even with the revision, rentals at the 1980 level are still very much below the current rentals. The HDB has no further plans at the moment to review rentals for its business or industrial premises.

    It would not be good for the HDB to start reducing its rentals because of poor business. If businessmen know that the HDB is prepared to reduce rentals because of poor business, they will not mind submitting high bids in order to get a shop unit and subsequently appealing for a reduction in rental because of poor business. This will make tender bids extremely high and is not beneficial to the economy. The HDB does allow businessmen, who are unable to continue paying their rentals, the option of terminating their tenancies and re-tendering for the same or new remises at a lower rental.

Column: 818



    (b) The selling prices of HDB flats have never been pegged to conditions in the private property market. HDB selling prices are determined by factors like land cost, construction cost and, most importantly- affordability of applicants. As a result, HDB selling prices are always well below prices of comparable private flats. The HDB 3-room simplified flats sell at $412 per sq metre, ie, less than $40 per sq foot, in New Towns, and $509 per sq metre in an Inner Suburban Zone. This is a fraction of comparable flats in the private sector. It is Government's policy to keep HDB selling prices within the reach of practically all Singaporeans in order to achieve the objective of 100% home ownership by 1999.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the Minister's reply that the HDB has only reviewed shop rentals once in the last 20-25 years, what is the HDB's future policy in this regard? Will there be a periodic review of shop rentals?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: It is likely that the HDB will have a periodic review of the policy on shop rentals but at a very much longer interval, not in the interval of two or three years. It will be a much longer interval.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, will it be of the same kind of interval as in the past, namely, 20-25 years?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am in no position to commit future governments of having one review in 20-25 years. But I think the period will be shorter than 20-25 years.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, is it conceivable that it will be within the ministerial lifetime of this Minister?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I think the lifetime of the Minister is also unpredictable.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, should the Hon. Minister not make a distinction between difficulties faced by individual shop-keepers who have tendered for high rentals and the general market conditions in which many shopkeepers are finding themselves today? And if that is so, should

Column: 819

the HDB not give special consideration to the difficulties faced by shopkeepers all over Singapore today?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB has taken this into consideration. That is why I said earlier that the HDB has no proposal to review the rentals. As for those who feel that they are paying too high a rental which they have tendered, they have the option of terminating the tenancy and either tender for the same shop or tender for another shop.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, is the Hon. Minister aware that in September last year, there was a further revision already agreed upon, which is the third stage of the shop rental increase?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I will give the answer when we come to Question 7.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question for the Minister on the sale of residential flats. Will the Minister be good enough to say what relationship do the construction costs bear to the selling price?

     Mr Speaker: Is your supplementary question relevant to the original question?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Yes, because we are talking about "downward revision of the prices of flats". It is under (b), Mr Speaker, Sir, and the Minister was saying that it is based on three factors, construction cost, land cost and affordability. So my question arises out of that, Mr Speaker, Sir.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, in fact, hon. Members are aware of how the prices of the HDB flats are fixed. It is based on these three factors. Construction cost is one of the factors. Land cost is another factor. But most important of all is the affordability of the Singaporeans. There is no point for the Government to build flats and fix high selling prices when Singaporeans cannot afford them. Also, Government has, in the Presidential Address, stated very clearly that for the next five years-, the HDB home ownership of Singaporeans will be increased to 80% from the present 60% of total population, and to 100% by the year 1999. So obviously the HDB's selling

Column: 820

prices of flats have to be pegged in such a way that the whole population can become flat owners.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sorry. But will the Minister please answer my question? It is very simple. What relationship do the construction costs bear to the selling price? Are the construction costs lower or are they higher and, if so, by how much? Just simply answer that question.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the construction cost and the land cost are the two factors which constitute the cost of the flats. In the new towns, the construction cost constitutes the greater proportion of the total cost of HDB flats because land in the new town zones is cheaper. In the central area, for example, in the city, land prices are much higher and therefore the proportion of construction cost is lower.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, I am sorry, the Minister still has not answered my question. Finally, will he make open for inspection the tender documents submitted by contractors for construction of the units?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Yes, the HDB tender document is an open document. Anybody can purchase it. Even the hon. Member can purchase it. As soon as a tender has been received, the tender result is published in the notice board of the HDB office, almost immediately after the tender has been submitted. The hon. Member can send somebody to look at the tenders submitted today which, I think, is open at about 10.30 or 11.00 am. The result will be published at 12 o'clock on the HDB notice board. So the hon. Member can get that information.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye (Rochore): Can the Minister elucidate the great variations in the ratio of land price to total investment?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, these are based on two factors, ie, the time and the type of building. For example, in the year 1978 the land cost represented only 11% because at that time the land price was low and so the tender price for URA sales was low and, therefore, the land price to total investment was low. In another example, in 1981, on the 9th sale the land price constituted 46% of total development because in 1981 there was the property boom.
